Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Developing a Community Aquaplanet Model
Award.AbstractNarration:
Under this RAPID project, a fully-documented community version of the aquaplanet configuration of the Community Atmospheric Model (CAM4) and CAM5 will be developed in time for the next version of the Community Earth System Model (CESM), currently scheduled for summer of 2016. The model can be run either with prescribed SST or coupled to a slab mixed-layer ocean. The model development process will include gathering input to understand the community's needs along with numerical experimentation to design the optimal functionality of the model. The software group at National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) will facilitate the development of the model for community use; the PI and her team will perform Diagnostic, Evaluation and Characterization of Klima (DECK) experiments following the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP6) protocols and prepare manuscripts documenting the model's behavior.

The project will result in a tool that can be effectively used by other researchers in the climate science community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our NSF-RAPID project (AGS-1547910) was designed to advance the development, ease-of-use, and documentation of a type of simplified climate model called an "aquaplanet".  Aquaplanet models, those in which all land masses are removed in favor of a global ocean, are simplified versions of the traditionally more complex global climate models.  The aquaplanet model configuration, combined with complementary simplifications to sea-surface temperature patterns, atmospheric chemical composition, and orbital settings, allows scientists to more effectively highlight and understand prominent weather and climate behaviors.  Aquaplanets also facilitate investigations into how statistical representations of physical processes not resolved on the model grid, like cumulus clouds, affect grid-resolved processes like large-scale circulations.  Idealized models like aquaplanets represent a vital component of a hierarchy of model complexity aimed at improving our understanding of comprehensive climate models and the physical underpinnings of the climate system.  We furthered the development of the aquaplanet configuration in the Community Earth System Model (CESM), one of the most widely used climate models in the global research community.  Prior to this project, CESM provided little or no support to users wanting to perform aquaplanet simulations; in some cases, formulating a correct CESM aquaplanet configuration required numerous steps and expert knowledge.  From a technical standpoint, our work has successfully and significantly simplified the aquaplanet configuration process.  From a scientific perspective, climate simulations conducted with the newly developed aquaplanet CESM provide intriguing findings related to the behavior of precipitation in present-day and warming climates.

Our project has resulted in numerous technological enhancements to the aquaplanet CESM.  What once required climate modelers to modify multiple settings in multiple files in order to set up the aquaplanet has been distilled to a single command.  Users are no longer required to search for or create input data files specific to the aquaplanet model setup.  The input files now provided by default, combined with updated and detailed documentation and supporting programs, can be used as templates that allow users to easily set up and customize their configuration.  With greater ease-of-use and documentation, our model development accomplishments make the CAM-aquaplanet accessible to a wider audience in the research community and thus provide a platform that facilitates better understanding of the climate system.  These CESM-aquaplanet improvements will be incorporated into the next public release of CESM and will allow all in the climate research community to leverage this simpler model version for scientific exploration well beyond the scope of the current project.

The general statistical distribution and occurrence of extremely intense precipitation are fundamental in shaping Earth’s climate and have critical socio-economic impacts, yet such phenomena are poorly represented in global climate models.  Climate simulations performed with the newly developed CESM aquaplanet model reveal strong sensitivities of precipitation patterns and intensities to details of the model configuration.  In present-day climate conditions, dual bands of heavier rainfall occur just to the north and south of the Equator, but the intensity of these dual bands and their separation distance in latitude is strongly dependent on the grid resolution of the model as well as the exact representation of unresolved physical processes (the "physics parameterization scheme").  We hypothesize that the representation of tall cumulus clouds, and the interaction of such clouds with shallower clouds and the processes that govern cloud formation, may be driving the observed precipitation pattern sensitivities.  The CESM aquaplanet is also found to produce precipitation too readily, with very few dry days particularly within the tropics.  This finding, combined with other results in the scientific literature, suggests that the dearth of "dry" days in CESM is associated more closely with local interactions between the atmosphere and ocean rather than differences in large-scale circulation patterns among various CESM configurations.  In a warming climate, the dual equatorial rainfall bands intensify, but the degree of intensification is highly dependent on the choice of physics representation.  Warming climates also yield more frequent episodes of extremely intense tropical rainfall, but the behavior is again sensitive to the choice of the physics parameterization scheme, with the most modern version of the parameterization scheme yielding the largest increase in extreme precipitation.  Identification and understanding of such model behaviors is vital to accurately interpreting the response and uncertainty of simulated precipitation patterns and extreme rainfall events in the present day and in projected climate states.  We expect our findings to seed future research into the more detailed mechanisms that explain the behaviors of time-averaged and extreme rainfall discovered as part of this project. ?
